scientificName: Allium fistulosum (Welsh onion) or young Allium cepa
description: Also known as scallions or green onions, these are young onions harvested before the bulb has swollen. They have a long, green stalk and a small, white undeveloped bulb, offering a milder flavor than mature onions.
regions: Widely cultivated globally, especially in East Asia, Europe, and North America
seasons: Autumn (can be grown year-round in some climates)
healthBenefits: Excellent source of Vitamin K, important for bone health and blood clotting.
Good source of Vitamin C and Vitamin A.
Contains antioxidants and sulfur compounds with potential health benefits.

potentialAllergies.name: Allium Sensitivity
potentialAllergies.details: Some individuals may experience digestive upset if sensitive to allium vegetables.

cultivationProcess:
Step-by-Step Growing Guide:
1. Planting: Can be grown from seeds or sets. Sow seeds in early spring or late summer.
2. Soil: Well-drained, fertile soil rich in organic matter. pH 6.0-7.0. Full sun to partial shade.
3. Spacing: Sow seeds thinly. Can be grown closely together in clumps or thinned for larger individual plants.
4. Watering: Keep soil consistently moist.
5. Harvesting: Harvest when stalks are pencil-thick or desired size. Pull entire plant or cut above roots for regrowth (for some types).
growthDuration: 60-80 days from seed; faster from sets.
sustainabilityTips: Store spring onions wrapped in a damp paper towel in the refrigerator crisper, or upright in a jar with a little water covering the roots.
Use both the white bulb and green stalk portions. Green tops are milder.
Can be regrown by placing the root ends in water.
carbonFootprintInfo: Low, especially when grown locally (0.2-0.5 kg CO2e/kg).

staticRecipes.name: Simple Stir-fried Spring Onions
staticRecipes.description: A quick and easy way to cook spring onions, bringing out their mild sweetness.
ingredients: 1 bunch spring onions, trimmed and cut into 1-2 inch pieces (separate white/light green and dark green parts)
1 tbsp oil (e.g., sesame or vegetable oil)
Optional: a splash of soy sauce or a sprinkle of toasted sesame seeds
steps: Wash spring onions thoroughly. Trim root ends and any wilted tops. Cut into 1-2 inch pieces, keeping the white/light green parts separate from the dark green tops.
Heat oil in a skillet or wok over medium-high heat.
Add the white and light green parts of the spring onions (and garlic, if using). Stir-fry for 1-2 minutes until slightly softened and fragrant.
Add the dark green tops and stir-fry for another 1-2 minutes until wilted but still bright green.
Season with salt. If desired, add a splash of soy sauce in the last 30 seconds of cooking.
Garnish with toasted sesame seeds if using. Serve immediately as a side dish or topping.

staticRecipes.name: Scallion Pancakes (Cong You Bing - Simplified)
staticRecipes.description: A savory Chinese flatbread folded with oil and minced scallions.
ingredients: 3/4 cup hot water (just off the boil)
steps: In a large bowl, add flour. Gradually pour in hot water while stirring with chopsticks or a fork until a shaggy dough forms. Then, add cold water and mix until a dough comes together. Knead on a lightly floured surface for 5-7 minutes until smooth. Cover and let rest for 30 minutes.
Divide dough into 4-6 equal pieces. Roll each piece into a thin circle (about 8 inches).
Brush the surface of the circle lightly with sesame oil, sprinkle with salt and chopped spring onions.
Roll the circle up tightly like a cigar. Then, coil the cigar into a spiral or snail shape. Tuck the end under.
Gently flatten the spiral with your palm, then roll it out again into a thin pancake (about 1/4 inch thick).
Heat a little oil in a non-stick skillet over medium heat. Cook pancake for 2-3 minutes per side, until golden brown and crispy.
Cut into wedges and serve hot with dipping sauce (e.g., soy sauce with vinegar and chili oil).

staticRecipes.name: Garnish with Fresh Spring Onions
staticRecipes.description: Using thinly sliced spring onions as a fresh, flavorful garnish for various dishes.
steps: Wash spring onions thoroughly. Trim root ends and any wilted parts of the green tops.
Thinly slice the spring onions, both the white/light green and dark green parts, depending on preference (dark greens are milder).
Sprinkle generously over soups (like ramen or pho), stews, stir-fries, omelets, salads, noodles, rice dishes, or savory pancakes just before serving.
They add a fresh, mild onion flavor, a pop of color, and a slight crunch.
